data.title: History museums in Ohio: All 125 museums to visit (August 2024)
data.meta_description: View a list of all history museums in Ohio (United States) for you to visit.
data.text:
The SS William G. Mather, a retired Great Lakes bulk freighter, is now a museum ship in Cleveland, Ohio. It is one of only five such museum ships in the Great Lakes region. This historic vessel, which once transported cargo such as ore, coal, stone, and grain to ports throughout the Great Lakes, has been meticulously restored and is now open to the public for exploration and learning.

The National Museum of the United States Air Force, also known as NMUSAF, is the official museum of the U.S. Air Force. It is situated at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Riverside, which is near Dayton, Ohio. This location is significant as it is one of the largest museums in the world and the oldest military aviation museum.

The USS Cod is not just a piece of history, but it is also a national historic landmark. It has been preserved as a memorial museum ship and is permanently moored in Cleveland, Ohio. The submarine is open to visitors every day from May 1 to September 30, offering a unique opportunity to explore a piece of naval history.

The Great Serpent Mound is a significant American Indian mound located on the Serpent Mound crater plateau, along the Ohio Brush Creek in Adams County, in the southern part of the U.S. state of Ohio. This location is not only historically significant but also offers a unique natural setting, surrounded by a cliff and woods.

The Cleveland Museum of Art, located in Cleveland, Ohio, is a highly esteemed institution in the realm of American fine arts and archaeology. It is one of the wealthiest and most reputable museums in the country, boasting a financial endowment of $755 million and attracting approximately 700,000 visitors annually.

The Cleveland Public Library, established in 1869, is a comprehensive library system that includes the Main Library located on Superior Avenue in downtown Cleveland. In addition to the Main Library, the system also comprises 27 branches scattered throughout the city, a mobile library, a Public Administration Library housed in City Hall, and the Ohio Library for the Blind and Physically Disabled. This extensive network of libraries offers a wide range of resources and services to the public.

The USS Cod, registered in the National Register of Historic Places on January 14, 1986, is now a national historic monument. It is preserved as a commemorative museum ship and is permanently moored in Cleveland, Ohio. The submarine is open to visitors every day from May 1 to September 30, offering a unique opportunity to explore a piece of naval history.

Stan Hywet Hall is a historic house museum located in Akron, Ohio. The estate spans over 28.3 hectares and includes a variety of attractions such as gardens, a greenhouse, a carriage house, and the main mansion. The mansion is one of the largest houses in the United States, making it a significant point of interest for visitors.

The National Museum of the Great Lakes is situated in the Toledo Maritime Center, a heritage location on the banks of the Maumee River on the east side of Toledo, Ohio. This museum, operated by the Great Lakes Historical Society, celebrates the natural and built heritage of the North American Great Lakes from a U.S. perspective.

Fort Ancient is recognized as the largest prehistoric hill fort in the United States. It boasts three and a half miles of walling within a 100-acre complex. This vastness provides a unique opportunity for visitors to immerse themselves in the grandeur of prehistoric Native American architecture.

The Weltzheimer/Johnson House, located in Oberlin, Ohio, is a unique example of Usonian style architecture, designed by the renowned architect Frank Lloyd Wright. Constructed in 1948 and 1949, this house stands as a testament to Wright's innovative design principles and his vision for affordable middle-class homes in post-World War II America.

The Pro Football Hall of Fame, located in Canton, Ohio, is a dedicated space that honors the significant contributions of athletes, coaches, and officials from the National Football League (NFL). It serves as a testament to the rich history and development of American Football.

Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park is a significant site in Dayton, Ohio, United States. It is dedicated to commemorating the contributions of three notable figures - Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright, and poet Paul Laurence Dunbar. Their work in the Miami Valley is celebrated and preserved within the park.

The Kirtland Temple has been recognized for its historical significance and architectural value. It has been listed in the National Register of Historic Places since June 1969. Furthermore, in December 1976, the temple was granted the status of a National Historic Landmark. These recognitions highlight the temple's importance in the history of the Community of Christ and its architectural uniqueness.

The Allen County Museum, situated in Lima, Ohio, is a vast establishment that spans multiple buildings. These buildings house a variety of collections, making it a place of diverse historical and cultural interest. The museum's expansive area allows it to accommodate a wide range of exhibits, providing visitors with a comprehensive view of the region's history and culture.

The William Howard Taft National Historic Site is a protected area located in Cincinnati, Ohio. This site is dedicated to preserving the birthplace of the United States President, William Howard Taft. It offers a unique opportunity for visitors to explore the historical significance of this location and learn more about the life and legacy of President Taft.

The International Women's Air & Space Museum (IWASM) is located in Cleveland, Ohio. It is dedicated to preserving the history of women in aviation and space, and documenting their ongoing contributions. This museum provides a unique opportunity to learn about the significant roles women have played in these fields.

The Harriet Beecher Stowe House, located in Cincinnati, Ohio, is a historic home that once served as the residence of Harriet Beecher Stowe, a prominent antislavery author. Stowe is best known for her 1852 novel, Uncle Tom's Cabin, which played a significant role in shaping public opinion on slavery during the 19th century.

The Kelton House Museum and Garden, located in the Discovery District of Downtown Columbus, Ohio, is a Greek Revival and Italianate mansion. This architectural style is a testament to the historical significance of the building and provides a unique aesthetic experience for visitors.

The Ohio River Museum is a maritime institution that provides an interpretation of the history of the Ohio River. It offers a unique perspective on the river's past, making it a fascinating destination for those interested in maritime history and the Ohio River's role in it.

The SS William G. Mather, a retired Great Lakes bulk freighter, is now a museum ship located in Cleveland, Ohio. It is one of only five such museum ships in the Great Lakes region. This historic vessel offers a unique insight into the maritime history of the area and the important role that freighters played in the region's economy.

The Marblehead Lighthouse, situated in Marblehead on Lake Erie in Ottawa County, Ohio, holds the distinction of being the oldest American lighthouse of the Great Lakes. Today, it forms an integral part of the Marblehead Lighthouse State Park, offering visitors a glimpse into its rich history and stunning views of the surrounding landscape.

The Ohio History Center, located in Columbus, Ohio, serves as a history museum and research center. It is the main museum for the history of Ohio and also functions as the headquarters, offices, and library of the Ohio History Connection. This makes it a significant location for anyone interested in learning about Ohio's past.

The John Rankin House, located at 6152 Rankin Hill Road in Ripley, Ohio, is a historic house museum that was built in 1828. It was the residence of Presbyterian abolitionist John Rankin and served as one of the original stops on the Underground Railroad. This significant historical site offers a glimpse into the life of John Rankin and the role he played in the abolitionist movement.

The John P. Parker House, located at 300 North Front Street in Ripley, Ohio, is a historic house museum that was once the home of former slave and inventor John P. Parker from 1853 until his death in 1900. This house is a significant part of American history, as it was the residence of a man who, despite being born into slavery, became an inventor and a prominent figure in the abolitionist movement.

The William Oxley Thompson Memorial Library, commonly referred to as the Thompson Library, is the primary library at Ohio State University's Columbus campus. It is the largest library of the university and serves as the central research library for the entire campus. Named in honor of the university's fifth president, William Oxley Thompson, the library houses the main stacks, special collections, rare books, and manuscripts, along with many departmental subject libraries.

The Museum of Catholic Art and History, previously known as the Jubilee Museum and Catholic Cultural Center, is a significant cultural institution located on Broad Street in Downtown Columbus, Ohio. The museum reopened its doors to the public in late 2021 after a period of closure.

The Milton and Tamar Maltz Performing Arts Center at Temple–Tifereth Israel is a significant historic arts and religious venue. It is located on the campus of Case Western Reserve University, on the border of Hough and University Circle at Silver Park in Cleveland, Ohio. The center can accommodate up to 1200 people, making it a substantial venue for various performances and events.

Beaver Creek State Park, located in Columbiana County, Ohio, is a vast public recreation area spanning 2,722 acres. The park is situated near East Liverpool, on the banks of Little Beaver Creek, offering visitors a chance to immerse themselves in nature's beauty.

The African American Museum in Cleveland, Ohio, is a significant cultural institution founded in 1953 by Icabod Flewellen. The museum is located in a historic Carnegie Library building that is over a century old. This establishment is dedicated to educating the public about the positive contributions of African Americans to global cultures and aims to dispel distorted portrayals of black people.

The Dawes Arboretum, located in Newark, Ohio, is a nonprofit organization that spans nearly 2,000 acres. This vast area is home to a variety of plant collections, gardens, and natural areas, offering a diverse range of flora for visitors to explore.

The Fire Museum of Greater Cincinnati, also known as the Cincinnati Fire Museum, is a place where visitors can explore the rich history of firefighting in Greater Cincinnati, Ohio. The museum is dedicated to preserving and showcasing firefighting artifacts, as well as honoring the firefighters who have served in the past and those who continue to serve today.

The Peter G. Thomson House, also known as Laurel Court, is a significant historic building located in Cincinnati, Ohio. It was officially listed in the National Register on November 29, 1979, marking it as a site of considerable historical importance. This recognition not only highlights the architectural significance of the building but also its historical relevance in the region.

Thurber House, located in Columbus, Ohio, is a literary center that was once the home of renowned author, humorist, and New Yorker cartoonist James Thurber. This historic house now serves as a hub for readers and writers, promoting the literary arts and commemorating Thurber's significant contributions to literature and art.

Ohio Village, located in Columbus, Ohio, is a living history museum that provides a firsthand view of life in Ohio during the American Civil War. The museum is operated by the non-profit organization, Ohio History Connection. It offers an immersive experience into the past, allowing visitors to explore the lifestyle, culture, and history of Ohio in the 19th century.

The American Classical Music Hall of Fame and Museum is located in the Hamilton County Memorial Building, which is situated next to the Cincinnati Music Hall in the Over-the-Rhine neighborhood of Cincinnati, Ohio. This location is not only historically significant but also conveniently located for visitors.

The Western Reserve Historical Society (WRHS) is a historical society based in Cleveland, Ohio. It operates the Cleveland History Center, which is a collection of museums located in University Circle. The society was founded in 1867, making it the oldest cultural institution in Northeast Ohio. The focus of WRHS is on the history of the Western Reserve, and it celebrated its 150th anniversary in 2017.

The Ohio Railway Museum, founded in 1948, is situated in Worthington, Ohio, in close proximity to Columbus, Ohio. As one of the oldest organizations involved in the preservation of railroad equipment and history in North America, it offers a unique insight into the evolution of rail transport.

Carillon Historical Park is a sprawling 65-acre park and museum located in Dayton, Ohio. The park is home to a variety of historic buildings and exhibits that delve into the history of technology and the evolution of Dayton and its residents from 1796 to the present day. As a visitor, you can explore the different sections of the park, each dedicated to a specific theme such as settlement, transportation, invention, and industry.

Roscoe Village, located in Coshocton, Ohio, is a restored town that was originally part of the Ohio and Erie Canal system. The village was first established in 1816 and was later renamed Roscoe in 1830. This historical site offers a glimpse into the past, showcasing the transformation of a small community into a thriving port along the Ohio and Erie Canal.

The Campus Martius Museum is a significant institution that provides insights into Ohio's history. It serves as a platform for understanding the state's past, offering a comprehensive view of the events and developments that have shaped Ohio. The museum's exhibits and collections are designed to educate and engage visitors, making it a worthwhile destination for those interested in learning more about Ohio's history.

Oak Hill Cottage is a historic Gothic Revival brick house located at 310 Springmill Street in Mansfield, Ohio. It was built in 1847 by John Robinson, who was the superintendent of the Sandusky, Mansfield, and Newark Railroad. The house is known for its Carpenter Gothic ornamentation and has been preserved with all of its original furnishings and artifacts from the 1870s.

Wildwood Preserve Metropark is a unique blend of nature reserve and historic estate, situated in the scenic Sylvania Township, Ohio. This location offers visitors the opportunity to explore the natural beauty of the area while also delving into its rich history. The park is a popular destination for both locals and tourists alike, making it a worthwhile addition to any travel itinerary.

Woodland Cemetery and Arboretum, situated at 118 Woodland Avenue, Dayton, Ohio, holds the distinction of being one of the oldest garden cemeteries in the United States. It was incorporated in the year 1842 by John Whitten Van Cleve, the first male child born in Dayton. This historical significance adds a unique charm to the place, making it a point of interest for visitors.

The Cozad–Bates House, also known as the Cozad–Bates House Interpretive Center, holds the distinction of being the oldest and only surviving pre-Civil War structure in University Circle, Cleveland, Ohio. This historical significance makes it a unique destination for those interested in American history, particularly the Civil War era.

The Thomas Alva Edison Birthplace, located at 9 Edison Drive in Milan, Ohio, is a historic house museum. It was built in 1841 and is a significant site as it was the birthplace of the renowned American inventor, Thomas Alva Edison. This location offers a unique opportunity to explore the early life and environment of one of the most influential inventors in history.

The Sherman House Museum, also known as the John Sherman Birthplace, is a historic house museum situated at 137 East Main Street in Lancaster, Ohio. This location is significant as it was the childhood home of John Sherman, a notable politician and statesman, and his older brother, General William T. Sherman, a Union Army General. The museum primarily focuses on the life and achievements of General Sherman.

The Perkins Stone Mansion, located in Akron, Ohio, United States, is a historic house museum. This mansion offers a glimpse into the past, showcasing the history and culture of the region. Visitors can explore the mansion and its grounds, learning about the people who lived there and the time in which they lived.

The Dr. Robert Smith House, also known as Dr. Bob's Home, is a historic house museum located at 855 Ardmore Avenue in Akron, Ohio. This house is significant as it was the home of Dr. Bob Smith, one of the co-founders of Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), from 1915 to 1950. It is now a museum dedicated to the history of AA, operated by the Founders Foundation.

The Daniel McCook House, located in Carrollton, Ohio, is a historic antebellum house that was once home to several members of the 'Fighting McCooks', a family that gained prominence during the American Civil War. This house provides a glimpse into the lives of this notable family and their contributions during a significant period in American history.

The Ohio Statehouse, a building of Greek Revival style, was inaugurated in 1857. This architectural style is characterized by its grandeur and elegance, making it a notable landmark in Columbus. The building's history and architectural style may be of interest to tourists who appreciate historical architecture.

The Lloyd Library and Museum is a unique institution located in the heart of downtown Cincinnati, Ohio. As an independent research library, it offers a wealth of knowledge and resources for those interested in a variety of scientific and historical subjects. Its central location makes it easily accessible for tourists visiting the city.

The Central Ohio Fire Museum, located in Downtown Columbus, Ohio, is a unique destination that offers a glimpse into the history of firefighting. The museum is housed in the former Engine House No. 16 of the Columbus Fire Department, a building with a rich history dating back to 1908. This historic building adds an extra layer of authenticity to the museum experience, making it a fascinating place to visit for those interested in history, architecture, or firefighting.

The National Veterans Memorial and Museum (NVMM) is a significant landmark in the United States, dedicated to the veterans of the U.S. Armed Forces. It is situated in Columbus, Ohio, making it a notable destination for those interested in military history and the personal stories of veterans. The museum's location along the Scioto River between Franklinton and Downtown Columbus adds to its appeal, offering visitors a scenic view of the city.

The Overfield Tavern, an early-nineteenth-century establishment, is situated along the banks of the Great Miami River in Troy, Ohio. Today, it is open to the public as a house museum, offering visitors a glimpse into the past.

The Lane–Hooven House, located in Hamilton, Ohio, is a historic house museum that was constructed in 1863. It was built for Clark Lane, a prominent industrialist and philanthropist of Hamilton. This unique structure stands as a testament to the rich history and architectural prowess of the period.

The Jeremiah Reeves House and Carriage House, also known as the Dover Historical Museum and the J.E. Reeves Victorian Home and Carriage House Museum, is situated at 325 East Iron Avenue in Dover, Tuscarawas County, Ohio. This location is significant as it is easily accessible for tourists and provides a historical context for the area.

The Cincinnati Reds Hall of Fame and Museum is a tribute to the rich history of the Cincinnati Reds franchise. It showcases the team's past through a variety of mediums including displays, photographs, and multimedia. This allows visitors to immerse themselves in the team's history and gain a deeper understanding of its legacy.

The Friends Meetinghouse is a significant historical site located near OH 150 in the village of Mount Pleasant, Ohio. Constructed in 1814, this Quaker meeting house holds a special place in American history. It was recognized for its historical importance and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1970. The building stands as a testament to the Quaker community's long-standing presence in the region.

The Avery-Hunter House, located at 221 East Broadway in Granville, Ohio, is a registered historic house. It was officially listed on the National Register on December 27, 1979. This recognition highlights the historical significance of the house, making it a point of interest for those interested in history and architecture.

The National Underground Railroad Freedom Center is a museum located in downtown Cincinnati, Ohio. The museum is dedicated to the history of the Underground Railroad, a network of secret routes and safe houses established in the United States during the early to mid-19th century, used by enslaved African-Americans to escape into free states and Canada. The museum's location in Cincinnati is significant as the city played a crucial role in the history of the Underground Railroad, with many slaves crossing the Ohio River from the southern slave states to find refuge in the city.

The Cincinnati History Museum is an urban history museum located in Cincinnati, Ohio, United States. It provides a comprehensive overview of the city's history and its evolution over the years. The museum is a great place for tourists who are interested in learning about the history of Cincinnati and its impact on the broader American history.

The Cooke-Dorn House, also known as the Eleutheros Cooke House, is a three-story, limestone Greek Revival style house located at 1415 Columbus Avenue in Sandusky, Ohio. This historic house was built in 1844 and stands as a testament to the architectural style of the time.

The Finnish Heritage Museum in Fairport Harbor, Ohio, is a non-profit organization dedicated to preserving and promoting Finnish heritage and cultural traditions. The museum's mission is to educate its members and the public about Finnish culture and history.

The First Ladies National Historic Site is a significant landmark located in Canton, Ohio. It was established in the year 2000 with the primary aim of commemorating all the First Ladies of the United States. This site serves as a tribute to the contributions and influences of these women, not just as wives of the Presidents, but as individuals who have played a crucial role in shaping the nation.

The Patterson Homestead is a historic house museum situated at 1815 Brown Street in Dayton, Ohio, United States. This location is easily accessible and offers a glimpse into the past, making it an interesting destination for tourists interested in history and architecture.

The William H. McGuffey House, a historic house museum, is situated at 401 East Spring Street, within the campus of Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, United States. This location offers visitors easy access to the museum as it is conveniently located within the university campus.

The Garst Museum houses a variety of exhibits that provide insights into different aspects of American history. These include exhibits about Annie Oakley, Lowell Thomas, Native American culture, local military activities, pioneer life, and prehistory. Each exhibit is meticulously curated to offer a comprehensive understanding of the subject matter.

The Johnson-Humrickhouse Museum is located in the historic Roscoe Village, a restored Ohio & Erie Canal town in Coshocton, Ohio. This general interest museum offers a unique glimpse into various aspects of history and culture, making it a worthwhile destination for tourists interested in a broad range of topics.

The Hancock Historical Museum, located in Findlay, Ohio, is dedicated to preserving the rich history of Hancock County. As a non-profit, privately funded institution, the museum is a member of the Ohio Local History Alliance and is situated in the Hull-Flater House at 422 West Sandusky Street. Founded in 1970 and opened to the public in 1971, the museum has been a cornerstone of historical preservation in the region for over half a century.

The William McKinley Presidential Library and Museum is a significant historical site dedicated to the 25th U.S. president, William McKinley. It is located in Canton, Ohio, where McKinley built his career. The museum is a repository of the largest collection of McKinley artifacts in the world, providing a comprehensive chronicle of the president's life and career.

The Dunham Tavern, also known as the Dunham Tavern Museum, holds the distinction of being the oldest building in Cleveland, Ohio. It is conveniently located at 6709 Euclid Avenue, making it easily accessible for visitors.

The Dittrick Museum of Medical History is located within the Dittrick Medical History Center of the College of Arts and Sciences of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Ohio. The museum is dedicated to the study of the history of medicine and houses a collection of rare books, museum artifacts, archives, and images. Established in 1898 by the Cleveland Medical Library Association, the museum functions as an interdisciplinary study center.

The International Peace Museum, located on the historic Courthouse Square in downtown Dayton, Ohio, is a non-profit institution dedicated to promoting a more equitable, civil, and peaceful world. The museum achieves this through education and collaboration, offering a variety of programs and exhibits that are non-partisan, secular, and focus on themes such as conflict resolution, equity, social justice, tolerance, and environmental protection.

The Westcott House, located in Springfield, Ohio, is a unique architectural gem designed by the renowned architect Frank Lloyd Wright. Built in 1908, this Prairie Style house was commissioned by Mr. Burton J. Westcott, his wife Orpha, and their family. The house stands as a testament to Wright's innovative design principles and the Westcott family's appreciation for unique architecture.

The Clark County Heritage Center, located in central Springfield, Ohio, is a building designed in the Romanesque architectural style. This style, popular in the 11th and 12th centuries, is characterized by round arches and heavy stone construction. The Center's design is a testament to this historical architectural style, making it a unique landmark in the area.

The Pennsylvania House, a historic inn and tavern, is located in western Springfield, Ohio. This three-story brick Federal structure was built around 1822 and is situated along the original National Road. It is also near the old road that connects Springfield with Dayton, Ohio. This location played a significant role in the early 19th century as a major transportation artery for those heading west or to Cincinnati.

The Wood County Museum, situated in Bowling Green, Ohio, is steeped in history. It stands on the original site of the Wood County Infirmary, which was also known as the Wood County Home or the Poor Farm. This establishment served as a home for the poor, mentally ill, physically disabled, and anyone in need of public assistance who were residents of Wood County.

The McCracken-McFarland House, located in Cambridge, Ohio, is a historic house that was built in 1825. This house is a significant part of the city's history and offers a glimpse into the past. It was once the home of a political leader and a Presbyterian minister, making it a site of interest for those interested in history and architecture.

The Museum of Ceramics is situated in the former East Liverpool Post Office, a significant historical building in itself. The museum houses an extensive collection of ceramic wares that were produced in and around East Liverpool, Ohio. This collection provides a comprehensive overview of the rich pottery history of the area, making it a fascinating destination for those interested in ceramics and history.

Hawthorn Hill, located in Oakwood, Ohio, is a historic house that served as the home of Orville Wright, his father Milton, and sister Katharine after 1914. The Wright brothers, Wilbur and Orville, had planned for it to be their joint residence, but unfortunately, Wilbur passed away in 1912, two years before the house was completed.

Glendower, also known as Glendower Historic Mansion and Arboretum, is a historic Greek Revival style house. It is located at 105 Cincinnati Avenue, U.S. Route 42, Cincinnati Avenue, in Lebanon, Ohio. This location is easily accessible and offers a glimpse into the architectural style of the past.

The Bethany Relay Station, now the National Voice of America Museum of Broadcasting, operated until 1994. The facility was named after the Liberty Township community of Bethany, which is located about two miles north of the museum.

Hale Farm and Village, located in Bath Township, Summit County, Ohio, is a historic property managed by the Western Reserve Historical Society. It is situated within the boundaries of the Cuyahoga Valley National Park, making it a unique blend of history and nature. The farm was originally the homestead of Jonathan Hale, a Connecticut farmer who migrated to the Western Reserve in 1810. Today, it serves as a living history museum, offering visitors a glimpse into the past.

The Northern Ohio Railway Museum is a non-profit, educational organization that was established in 1965. It is located near Chippewa Lake, Ohio, United States. The museum is dedicated to the collection, preservation, and exhibition of streetcars, artifacts, and assorted railway equipment related to the origin, development, and use of transit equipment and operations in northern Ohio.

The MAPS Air Museum is an aviation museum located in Green, Ohio, United States. It is managed by the Military Aviation Preservation Society, an organization dedicated to the preservation of aviation history. The museum is a significant destination for those interested in military aviation history, offering a wide range of exhibits and collections.

The Crawford Auto-Aviation Museum is a transportation museum located in Cleveland, Ohio, United States. It is a part of the Western Reserve Historical Society's Cleveland History Center in University Circle. This museum is a significant part of the city's cultural and historical landscape, offering visitors a unique insight into the evolution of transportation.

The Betts House, constructed in 1804, holds the distinction of being the oldest surviving building in Cincinnati and the oldest brick home in Ohio. This historic structure offers a unique glimpse into the city's past, showcasing the architectural style and construction methods of the early 19th century. It stands as a testament to the city's rich history and the resilience of its early settlers.

The National McKinley Birthplace Memorial Library and Museum, also known as the McKinley Memorial Library, Museum & Birthplace Home, is a significant monument dedicated to President William McKinley. Located in Niles, Ohio, the memorial is a grand marble structure measuring 232 by 136 by 38 ft. It is divided into two wings, each serving a unique purpose in preserving and showcasing the life and legacy of President McKinley.

The Grand River Lighthouse, which is now a maritime museum, is situated at Fairport Harbor on Lake Erie, at the mouth of the Grand River in Lake County, Ohio. This historic lighthouse was built in 1871 and was decommissioned in 1925, only to be replaced by the Fairport Harbor West Breakwater Lighthouse. Today, it serves as a significant historical site and a museum that offers a glimpse into the maritime history of the region.

The First Presbyterian Church of Wapakoneta holds the distinction of being the oldest Protestant church building in Auglaize County, and the oldest church building of any faith in the city of Wapakoneta. This makes it a significant landmark in the area, offering a unique insight into the religious history of the region.

The Heritage Village Museum is a unique attraction that offers a glimpse into the past. It is a recreated community from the 1800s, located in Southwestern Ohio, United States. This historical site provides an opportunity for visitors to experience life as it was in the 19th century, offering a unique perspective on the region's history.

The Southern Ohio Museum is situated in Portsmouth, Ohio, and caters to the southern and southeastern regions of the state. This location makes it easily accessible for visitors from these areas and beyond, offering a rich cultural experience steeped in local history and art.

The Harrison County History of Coal Museum, also known as the Puskarich Coal Museum, is a non-profit educational institution dedicated to the history and significance of coal mining. The museum offers a comprehensive insight into the coal mining industry, its history, and its impact on society and the environment. Visitors can expect to learn about the geological history of coal, the history of coal mining in the United States, how mines were built, and the role of coal in the environment.

The Ukrainian Museum-Archives is situated at 1202 Kenilworth Avenue, a location that was formerly a convent. This location is easily accessible and offers a unique setting for the museum, adding to the overall experience of the visit.

The Cleveland Hungarian Museum is dedicated to protecting and preserving the history of Hungarians in northeast Ohio. It offers a unique opportunity for tourists to learn about the Hungarian community's contributions and experiences in this region of the United States.

The Youngstown Historical Center of Industry and Labor is a museum located in Youngstown, Ohio. It is dedicated to preserving the history of the steel industry, which was a major part of the area's economic life throughout the 20th century. The museum provides a deep dive into the industrial past of the community, offering a unique perspective on the region's history.

The Pioneer and Historical Society of Muskingum County, also known as the Zanesville Historical Society, is a non-profit organization based in Zanesville, Ohio. Its mission is to preserve the history of the Zanesville and Muskingum County region. This society operates several significant historical sites in and around Zanesville, contributing to the rich historical tapestry of the area.

The Firelands Museum, located in Norwalk, Ohio, holds the distinction of being the oldest operating museum in the state. It was established by the Firelands Historical Society, which began its collection of artifacts as early as 1857. This long history of preservation and display makes the museum a significant destination for those interested in the history of Ohio and the broader region.
